questions.text: Which of the following is the method of choice for the purification of highly polluted water on a large scale?
questions.solution:
Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is done for purification of highly polluted water on a large scale.

Related Pearl: Purification of Water

Purification of water can be done on a large scale or small scale.

I) Purification of water on a large scale is done by one or more of the following measures:

  • Storage
  • Filtration:
    • Slow sand filters
    • Rapid sand filters
  • Disinfection:
    • Chlorination
    • Ozonation
    • UV radiation
    • Membrane processes like reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, ultrafiltration and microfiltration.

II) Purification of water on a small scale:

  • Household purification of water:
    • Boiling
    • Chemical disinfection using bleaching powder, chlorine solution, high test hypochlorite, chlorine tablets, iodine and potassium permanganate.
    • Filtration using Pasteur Chamberland filter, Berkefeld filters or Katadyn filters.
    • UV radiation
    • Multi-stage reverse osmosis
  • Disinfection of wells with bleaching powder

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding chlorination of water?

choices.text: Orthotolidine test measures only combined chlorine
Chlorine acts best when the  pH of water is around seven
It kills bacteria, viruses, spores and slime organisms
Hypochlorite ions are mainly responsible for its disinfectant activity

questions.solution:
Chlorine acts best when the pH of water is around seven because of the predominance of the hypochlorous acid. Most water sources have a pH  around 6.5–7, making chlorination an effective form of disinfection.

Option A: Orthotolidine test measures both free and combined chlorine in water.

Option C: Chlorination kills pathogenic bacteria, but has no effect on spores and certain viruses.

Option D: The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to hypochlorous acid.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

questions.text: You assign a male health worker at a sub-centre with the task of chlorinating public water resources. What is the minimum concentration of free residual chlorine that should be maintained for effective chlorination?

choices.text: 0.5 mg/litre for a contact period of 1 hour
0.5 mg/litre for a contact period of ½ hour
0.8 mg/litre for a contact period of 1 hour
0.8 mg/litre for a contact period of ½ hour

questions.solution:
The minimum recommended concentration of free residual chlorine for routine chlorination is 0.5 mg/litre for a contact period of 1 hour.

questions.text: As an epidemiologist, you are investigating an outbreak of cholera. What is the minimum free residual chlorine level that should be maintained in pipelines to prevent further spread of the outbreak?
questions.solution:
The minimum level of free residual chlorine to be maintained in pipelines following an outbreak of cholera is 0.5 mg/litre.

After a disaster (such as a flood), the water bodies are contaminated with sewage and drainage. The mixing of faeces in drinking bodies increases the risk of numerous microbial infections. The advisable level of free residual chlorine in water bodies after a disaster is, therefore, higher i.e. 0.7-0.9 mg/litre.

Minimum recommended free residual chlorine levels:

  • Cholera epidemic: 0.5 mg/litre
  • Disaster/ Natural calamities: 0.7 - 0.9 mg/litre

questions.text: The municipal corporation in your area is performing routine chlorination of drinking water supplies. Which of the following statements about chlorination is incorrect?

choices.text: Free chlorine is released in water after breakpoint chlorination
Chlorine demand is the amount needed to kill spores, protozoal cysts and helminthic ova
0.5 ppm of free chlorine must be present in water after the breakpoint has been reached
Contact period of 1 hour is necessary

questions.solution:
Chlorine demand is the amount of chlorine that is needed to kill bacteria, and to oxidize all the organic matter and ammoniacal substances in the water. It is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 1 hour) at a given temperature and pH of the water.

0.5 ppm (0.5 mg) of free chlorine must be present in water after the breakpoint has been reached.

questions.text: Which of the following tests identifies free and combined chlorine in water separately?
questions.solution:
Orthotolidine-arsenite test determines both free and combined chlorine in water separately.

Orthotolidine test determines free and combined chlorine together.

Chick Martin test and Garrod's test are used to test the efficacy of disinfectants.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds is predominantly responsible for the disinfecting property of bleaching powder?
questions.solution:
The disinfectant property of bleaching powder is predominantly due to the action of hypochlorous acid. It is 70-80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.

Bleaching powder, also known as chlorinated lime (CaOCl2), has 33 per cent of chlorine in it. When chlorine is added to water, there is the formation of hydrochloric and hypochlorous acids. The hydrochloric acid is neutralized by the alkalinity of the water. The hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen ions and hypochlorite ions, as follows:

H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl

HOCl → H + OCl

questions.text: A village health and sanitation team is planning to disinfect 100 wells. Which of the following is the most cost-effective method in this scenario?
questions.solution: Disinfection of wells using bleaching powder is the most widely used and cheapest method.

questions.text: An outbreak of viral hepatitis A has been reported in a village. On investigating, you find a contaminated well in the locality to be the source of the outbreak. Which of the following methods would you advise for chlorinating the well in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The double pot method is used for disinfecting wells by chlorination in emergencies like hepatitis A outbreak in a village.

Double pot method has an inner and outer pot, each with a hole in it and covered with a polyethylene foil. The inner pot is filled with bleaching powder and coarse sand. The double pot system is then lowered into a well. This device can work satisfactorily for 2 – 3 weeks in small wells containing about 4500 litres of water.

questions.text: In your community medicine practicals, you are given an apparatus as shown in the image given below. Which of the following statements regarding the apparatus is true?

choices.text: The indicator used is bromocresol purple
It is used to estimate free chlorine levels
It is used to estimate combined chlorine levels

questions.solution:
The image given is that of a Horrock's apparatus. The indicator used in Horrock's apparatus is starch iodide.

Horrock's apparatus contains 6 white cups (200 ml each), 1 black cup with a circular mark, 2 metal spoons with 2 grams of bleaching powder in each, 7 glass stirring rods, 1 special pipette and 2 droppers. It is not usful in measuring free and combined chlorine. It estimates the chlorine demand of water and is used to calculate the amount of bleaching powder used to disinfect the well.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: What is the amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 litres of water if the 4th, 5th, and 6th cups of a Horrock’s apparatus show distinct blue color?
questions.solution:
The dose of bleaching powder required is 8 grams.

It is given by (n x 2) gms for 455 litres of water, where n is the number of the first cup that shows distinct blue color. In this scenario, the dose of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 litres of water is (4 x 2) = 8grams.

questions.text: The water sample from a well is tested using Horrock’s apparatus. It is observed that the 3rd cup shows a blue color after the addition of the starch-iodine indicator. How much bleaching powder will be required to disinfect 2275 litres of the well water?
questions.solution:
The dose of bleaching powder required is 30 grams.

It is given by (n x 2) gms for 455 liters of water, where n is the number of the first cup that shows a distinct blue color.

In this scenario, the dose of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 liters of water is (3 x 2) = 6 grams.

Since 2275/455 = 5. The amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 2275 litres of water = 6 x 5 = 30 grams.

questions.text:
Which of the following agents have residual germicidal effect when used for treatment of water?
  1. UV radiation
  2. Ozone gas
  3. Chlorine
  4. Iodine
  5. Potassium permanganate
questions.solution:
Chlorine has residual germicidal effect when used for treatment of water.

 UV radiation, ozone gas, iodine and potassium permanganate have good germicidal action but do not have residual germicidal effect.

questions.text: Which of the following properties of ozone makes it less suitable for the disinfection of water on a large scale?

choices.text: Ozone requires a long time period for action
It has no residual disinfectant action

questions.solution:
Ozone has no residual disinfectant action.

Ozone gas can be used as a primary disinfectant of water in a large scale. Ozone disinfection is usually followed by biological filtration or granular activated carbon to prevent further contamination during distribution. Chlorine residual treatment is also done as ozone does not provide for a residual disinfectant action.

questions.text: Which of the following is a lower-pressure membrane process for treatment of water?
questions.solution:
Microfiltration is a lower-pressure membrane process used for the treatment of water.

Membrane processes are employed in the large scale treatment of water. They are classified as high-pressure processes and lower-pressure processes. 

  • High-pressure processes:
    • Reverse osmosis - Rejects monovalent ions and organic molecules of molecular weight > 50 daltons. It is most commonly used for desalination of brackish water and sea water. The membrane pore size is < 0.002 µm.
    • Nanofiltration - Allows monovalent ions such as sodium or potassium to pass but rejects a high proportion of divalent ions like calcium and magnesium and some higher molecular weight organics. The membrane pore size ranges from 0.001 – 0.01 µm. 
  • Lower-pressure processes:
    • Ultrafiltration - Rejects organic molecules of molecular weight > 800 daltons. The membrane pore size ranges from 0.002 - 0.003 µm.
    • Microfiltration - Rejects colloidal and suspended material. It does not separate molecules and is usually used before reverse osmosis. The membrane pore size ranges from 0.01 – 12 µm.
